handDesc.p: Halantas. T looks like a full-sized ta without a headmark (l21, l47); some specimens also have a short vertical tail, e.g. l21 balāT. N looks like a simplified and slightly reduced na without a headmark, with the top extended in a short tail slanting to the right (l10, l11, l17, l20 etc). M seems to be a circle without a tail, as in l22 bhuvaM. Rangacharya apparently sees no instances of final M in this text, but I am quite certain some final anusvāras in his edition are actually M.
Original punctuation marks are plain straight verticals, a character body in height.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is a dot after the character to which it belongs, placed at midline height or lower. Dependent o occurs both in the single-stroke cursive form and as two separate strokes. The cursive form (e.g. l2 gotrā°) has low humps identical on both sides, and a short tail descending barely below headline (but some instances, e.g. l16 kollabi°, have a longer tail, while others have none, ending well above headline, e.g. l18 tanayo). Dependent au (e.g. l3 kauśiki) does not differ conspicuously from cursive o and is read on the basis of context, without flagging as an erroneous o. The character dha is mostly written to look like va (e.g. (l1)). I, like Rangacharya, treat these as instances of dha, unclear due to unusual formation. Although most look like perfect specimens of va, not imperfect specimens of dha, there is also an instance of tha that looks like va with a dot in it (l6), while a normal-shaped tha occurs in l62. Normal-shaped dha also occurs (l25 vacadharasya, l33 °dhyakṣam). Because of this variation, I accept the va-like outline as an alternative form used by the scribe in question.

div.head: Seal

app.note: The vowel mark for ā is extended downward in a curve much like that for subscript r. This may be an ornamental extension of the stroke or an error made by an illiterate scribe, but it is definitely not a subscript y.

At this locus, Rangacharya marks the text from pratā to vallabhendrasya as superfluous. There is no way to tell which iteration of the (imperfectly) repeated string was inscribed in error, but since the second instance of vallabhendrasya contains a scribal correction (see next apparatus entry), I understand that its presence in the text was approved by a contemporary editor and it is the first iteration that was dismissed.
The addition is written below the line and to the right of bha, i.e. one character to the right of where I would expect it to be.
Typo or deliberate abridging in PVPS.
Typo in PVPS?

In addition to an extra light syllable in this word, the first pāda of this stanza also has a caesura between a prefix and a verb, which is permissible only by licence. Rangacharya's observation that The composition of this verse is faulty may refer to the metrical problem quarter or to its unintelligibility or both. His emendation, while it improves this particular word, only aggravates the metrical anomaly. PVPS's emendation is metrically and grammatically correct, but is too heavy-handed to accept. If I am correct in interpreting the composer's intent (for which see the translation), then the meaning could have been expressed in correct prosody, e.g. as vacasaḥ pateḥ kamala-saṁbhūtasya (though the inferior caesura remains here).
Though PVPS's emendation is not strictly necessary, I find it brilliant and very likely to reflect the composer's intent.

I cannot interpret the character tī (or possibly ti) written directly below vā in the line above and ignored by both previous editors. In the facsimile I see no indication that it has been deleted, but can only assume that it was engraved in error for the ntri required here, and the correct character was re-engraved to the right of it. It was probably not meant to be an addition, since it is equal or almost equal in size to the regular characters, whereas other interlinear additions are much smaller. There is also no apparent place where such an addition would have been required. This character was engraved before the rest of line 33 and slightly higher than the other characters of that line; the correct ntri is to the right of and below this one.
Probably a typo in PVPS's, where tre was typeset instead of his intended tīe. His emendation of the ending is probably grammatically correct, but I prefer not to make it in the edition.
PVPS's emendation makes good sense, but I am not sure it corresponds to the composer's intent.
Possibly a typo in PVPS.

Ranghacharya is more confident of this reading than I am, and his original rubbing may have been clearer than my scan. Nonetheless, vī seems to be quite clear. -cāṭa- is plausible from the rubbing, but in the context I would expect °tāri- or °tapra°, both of which would, however, require a major emendation. (PVPS in fact proposes the former of these, but I hesitate to introduce it to the text on account of its uncertainty.) The ra of vīra is wholly indistinct, but it may be possible to read this as vīri and emend to vairi, in which case ari is not needed earlier on, though I would still expect nirddārita rather than nirddāri.

While Rangacharya's emendation is also plausible in the context as I construe it (though not as he seems to have construed it based on his following emendation noted in the next apparatus entry), I prefer my emendation as being less invasive. PVPS may have been of the same opinion, though he ignores the anusvāra.
Here I agree with Rangacharya and PVPS that a visarga is not wanted; I am, however, not sure that one was indeed present in the original, though shown so by both previous editors.

The character at the end of line 37 seems in the scan to be ca, though VR reads it as cā; PVPS's edition shows ca, but macrons are routinely omitted by his typesetter, so I suspect that his reading was also cā. This is the simplest and least important issue with this locus. For reducing the dittography, previous editors suppress the string kubhalukya. While this leads to meaningful text with a small and straightforward suppression, it seems unlikely that these characters could have been erroneously engraved while the others were correct and deliberate. Much more likely in my opinion is that the engraver first started with śrīmac-calukya-ku, probably starting to engrave kula out of habit. Realising the mistake, he would have started again from the beginning of the stanza, but this time round, he did not connect the bottom of ca, so the character as engraved turned out as bha. My emendation is thus more complex than that of the previous editors, but presupposes much more feasible scribal mistakes. The final problem with this locus is that of śrīmac. Suppressing this word results in correct prosody for the line, but so does suppressing the subsequent vaṁśa (to obtain śrīmac-calukyodita-). I believe it is much more likely that śrīmac was, again out of habit, engraved unnecessarily (or perhaps conceived of as a bit of prose tagged on before the stanza). Moreover, with my emendation of the dittography, śrīmac is a natural part of the erroneously engraved string, whereas PVPS has to resort to a separate emendation to suppress it (while VR only notes that the stanza is metrically faulty, but does not attempt to correct it, though his editor does propose deleting śrīmac in a footnote.).
Possibly emend to -śrīr?

There seems to be a punctuation mark here, though no previous editor reads it and it would definitely be in the wrong place. The string ra-ma is indiscernible in the scanned estampage, though read as clear by both editors; in the next character, dh is plausible but in fact (like most other instances of dh) it looks more like v and may also be d or possibly something else. Next, the character read as nu by both previous editors is in fact a perfect specimen of gu, though I agree it was probably intended for nu. PVPS's emendation is heavy-handed and does not seem to improve the text.

VR's editor in a footnote proposes emending this word to nānyo. It is not clear to me how he sees this as an improvement to the text. If the reading is correct, then it certainly needs emendation to rectify the metre, and this purpose is served by this emendation as well as that of PVPS. However, it is possible that the plate in fact has nanū, a word that is not attested but which may be explained as nanu+u or as an elongation for the sake of the metre.

VR's editor proposes the same emendation in a footnote. It very probably reflects the intent of the composer, though given that the stanza as a whole is quite unintelligible, something else may have been intended, e.g. amuṁ, imaṁ or aho.

I believe the emendation I attribute above to PVPS reflects his intent. His footnote actually reads viśām-ityaksaṁṣṭa, which makes no sense to me. VR's editor in his footnote proposes viśāmiīty akṣācaṣṭa

The reading here is clear, and the problem is only segmentation into compounds and independent words. PVPS's note actually shows vāṭaṁ gata, but on the basis of his discussion of the contents (see my commentary) I believe he may have construed both of these words as in compound to the next word.

div.note: @@@Rangacharya’s editor suggests deleting śrīmat, emending nanu to nānyo, ama to ahaṁ and mityakṣaṣṭa to °mīty ācaṣṭa, after which he thinks the stanza “may yield some sense”.

div.p: PVPS's reconstruction of the stanza, proposed in a footnote separate from those suggesting individual emendations, runs like this, cālukya vaṁśodita bhūmipāla śrī-dvāram ājñānugatam praviśya| nūnam vipaddvāra mahaṁ viśām-ityaksaṁśṭa vāṭam gata vallabheśam||, with only the transliteration changed to DHARMA standard, but retaining his spaces and hyphens (including a hyphen at the end of a typographic line after śrī, but removing another at the end of a line in after ityaks. In his discussion of Kākatīya history (21) he paraphrases this stanza to say, Guṇḍiya Rāṣṭrakūṭa entered vipad-dvāra (the gate of risk) in order to help his master Vallabheśa while capturing Vāṭa or Vijayavāṭa, the capital of the Eastern Cālukya king.

Reported in 6A/1916-19171 with a description at 115-11624. First edited from inked impressions by V. Rangacharya (), with facsimiles but without translation. Re-edited by P. V. Parabrahma Sastry in Epigraphia Andhrica vol. I, p. 57ff, not traced. Part of this edition (lines 21 to 47) re-published in 305-3071. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Rangacharya's edition and the available part of Parabrahma Sastry's edition with Rangacharya's facsimiles.No image of the seal is available.
